awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Intersections of Labor, Language, and Value in the Production of Emerging Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
This dissertation project seeks to further understanding of the labor involved in producing language technologies, such as chatbots, large language models, and other artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled technologies. By focusing on the experiences of workers who create, curate, and label linguistic data, the researcher illuminates how everyday labor and decision-making shape new technologies as well as their social and cultural impacts. In addition to training a doctoral student in research methods and data analysis, this project improves public understanding of digital technologies and the data that animate them. Findings from the research will be shared with academic audiences across varied disciplines and with non-governmental organizations related to digital labor, language, and data. 

This project focuses on how language is valued and transformed in the context of producing new digital technologies. Specifically, the research examines the skills, tools, and rubrics used by various workers in the tech industry to generate and evaluate linguistic data. The researcher uses participant observation with a startup that is creating an AI-enabled language learning app, in addition to discourse analysis, semi-structured interviews, and life histories, to explore how language is made into data for technological ends. Additionally, the project asks how the experiences, career trajectories, and perspectives of workers inform the decisions they make throughout this process. In doing so, this dissertation research contributes to the social scientific study of technology by investigating how linguistic labor and workers’ understandings of language shape production. Moreover, this project sheds further light on the shifting nature of labor within an increasingly digital world.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The growing prominence of large language models (LLMs) and other data-driven language technologies has transformed linguistic data into a valuable resource within the information technology (IT) sector on a global scale. As the field of artificial intelligence (AI) increasingly moves toward 'deep learning' techniques, training models on massive datasets rather than pre-programmed rules, it is crucial for social scientists to devote attention to the processes of collecting, curating, and categorizing the linguistic data that animates these AI language models. As LLMs and their underlying training data become topics of public concern, it becomes essential to understand these behind-the-scenes processes and the decision-making rubrics that guide them.

In this context, this project used qualitative methods to examine: (1) how linguistic data is collected, curated, and categorized to train LLMs and other AI technologies; (2) the forms of labor and expertise required to carry out this work; and (3) how broader sociocultural and political-economic processes shape this labor. The study specifically focused on AI models for Arabic, an illuminating case study given that Arabic is typically classed as a 'low-resource language' for which relatively fewer datasets exist (or are accessible). Over the past several years, the Arabic-speaking world has witnessed a significant increase in efforts by both IT companies and academic institutions to create and curate Arabic-language datasets for model training; thus, it is an opportune time to conduct research on the everyday work and decision-making processes involved in this endeavor.

To address the project research questions, the researcher conducted 27 semi-structured interviews during the grant period with workers involved in the production of Arabic-language datasets and language models across a diverse array of roles, including proofreaders, data annotators, computational linguists, project managers, and engineers. Alongside interviews, the researcher also participated in a multi-day IT conference in Jordan to attend varied lectures, workshops, and exhibitions about trends in the development of artificial intelligence for Arabic. Finally, the researcher participated in the work and regular meetings of an ongoing project to create an AI model that can provide real-time feedback on the pronunciation of non-native Arabic learners.

Building on the collection and thematic analysis of qualitative data, including transcribed interviews and field notes, this study offers several preliminary findings that the researcher will further develop in future stages of the project:

  • Shifting Labor Relations: The shift towards the creation of LLMs, trained using massive datasets, has resulted in a growing demand for Arabic language workers within the IT sector. However, despite the desirability of linguistic expertise within the IT sector, the everyday forms of collaboration between engineers and language workers that were once a fixture of language technology development are increasingly less common. The results of the study suggest that shifting labor dynamics ought to be read alongside not only technological shifts but also changes in how workers in the industry conceptualize technology in relation to language. Put differently, the change in labor relations does not straightforwardly reflect shifts in how AI is made but also how engineers (and others who conceive of their work as 'technical') conceptualize language models as trained on numerical and spatial data (i.e., digits and vectors) rather than upon language itself. That said, the widening gulf between linguistic and technical expertise also aligns with labor fragmentation and outsourcing occurring in the IT industry more broadly.
  • Language and Conceptualization of AI Models: This study also makes a methodological contribution, suggesting that attention to the everyday speech of IT workers can offer a window into competing conceptions of language, technology, and artificial intelligence. This finding draws on and adds to a broader history of social-scientific scholarship that has analyzed the use of and contestation over the idioms utilized to convey information about emerging technologies, both within expert communities and in communication with broader publics. Specifically, this study argues that metaphors offer a useful entry point to consider how the production of language models is shaped by: (1) diverging conceptions of what constitutes artificial intelligence; (2) differences in how language and linguistic expertise are valued across organizational and political-economic contexts; and (3) competing understandings of the future of AI.  

In sum, this study advances our understanding of how labor dynamics, everyday language practices, and political-economic relations shape the production of large language models (LLMs) and other AI-enabled technologies, particularly across cultural and linguistic contexts. Additionally, this study has provided a U.S.-based doctoral student with the opportunity to further develop skills in qualitative methods and data analysis. The researcher has shared research findings in both Jordan and North America at two centers devoted to the study of language and culture. Findings from the research, moreover, will also be shared and discussed at academic conferences across multiple disciplines in the United States in the coming years.
